title: Before 1 May 2022, will the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) report 3.6 million or more total cases of COVID-19 in Canada?
preds: Still at 7k cases a day with only 10k to go to hit 3.6M.  Its done.
Just repeating my forecast to say that the question should resolve in approximately 5-7 more days.
Another 8k day on 8 April.  At this rate, with 3.55M you only need 6 more days at this rate to hit 3.6M.  I think its looking likely.
The gulf between rate of daily infections and maximum rate to fall under 3.6 million is too vast. 8k daily as of today (apr 9), compared to 2k to fall under.

3,552,502 as of April 7. 47,498 left to go. The 7-day average of reported cases/day is 6284. 47498 cases / 6000 cases/day = 7.9 days. It is the biological certainty that Covid spread will continue, coupled with the certainty of ongoing case reporting, that makes this a 100% forecast. It should resolve to yes within the next couple weeks.
Looking more and more the base that this threshold Will be breached.
april 6 has Canada needing 65k to hit the 3.6 million - with a continued upward trend of cases

Cases per day now over 7500 and wastewater surveillance in Ontario looking similar to the spike in end Dec/early Jan 2021 
https://covid19-sciencetable.ca/ontario-dashboard/#wastewatersignal
That makes the number seem much more likely to eclipse 3.6M by 1 May.
OnLy 2800 cases per day needed when current cases are still over 6k per day

All but done. 25 days to go, need average 3200 cases a day to hit it. This wave is ripping through Canada and my anecdotal evidence suggests the surge is still going strong. Suspect us to clear this easily.

Last April the rise in cases was pretty dramatic. i think it might mirror that after the B.A.2 surge over the winter. only 100,000 cases to go over the next month. in March the average was about 6200 cases per day. April needs only 3300 cases per day to break 3.6M total.
Still a high probability for this one

Today, reporting 3.51M cases due to some updating improvements?  That's 60k cases in 7 days which is way higher rate than the daily curves were showing between 4-5k per day.  Maybe I was looking at it last just before an update but the variability is still pretty high here.  So at this point,  we need 90k cases in a 30 weeks.  If this latest bump wasn't a one-time correction of some sort,  then hitting 90k cases in 3 weeks is looking pretty certain.  Increasing again but checking in a week to make sure it doesn't swing the other way.

3.51 million cases as of 2 April, with 7,919 on the last day. If that's repeated every day, it won't be enough to hit 3.6 million by end April.
Also, routine cases are no longer being tested or reported.
It looks like the target will hit in the next couple of weeks.

+35, cases have ticked up and makes this look very likely. https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Color+by+test+positivity=false&country=~CAN
Already at almost 3.5 Million, so a good chance that the total will top 3.6 by the end of April.  The trend at the moment is upward.
current rate is about 30% higher than what is needed. Ontario and Quebec seem to be increasing cases again . I am expecting to see a month of increases mirroring UK

30 days to go and we need to avg ~4,300 cases a day to close the gap. Over the last 30 days we averaged 5,900, over the last 14 days 6,300, over the last 7 days 6,800. Anecdotally people are dropping like flies in Toronto. Small sample obviously but the post Spring-break + general spread of this new variant is going to lead to a big pop in cases in my view. I think on average we should be able to clear 4,300/day given we'll be front end loaded >6,000 for some next week or so and then a slow decline to the back half.
Ok, today's data convinced me that the crowd is right.
Ontorio - peaking now, moved from 600K - 1M in jan/Feb, should add similar number in down phase

Continuing well ahead of pace to target. A 1 in 50 chance of falling off the pace substantially in one month's time seems about right.   I am struggling a bit to think of scenarios other than test shortages of some kind that would get the kind of fast sustainable drop in case levels.  We had floods here in Australia that cut cases by half as people couldn't go out.   This is clearly the realm of very rare events.
currently on an uptick - canada would need approx 4500 cases a day avg to exceed 3.6 million by 1 may - which is currently less than their daily reported average

It seems clear now the plateau/reversal of the downward trend is not simply noise. This makes sense as the country has been lifting mask and vaccine restrictions in recent weeks. At current 7-day average levels should easily hit the threshold before the deadline. The fact that I suspect the 7-day average will float at least higher for a bit means it seems impossible the case rate will drop fast enough from here to keep the number below the threshold.

The average daily new cases has finally flattened (was on the rise). Even so, with only 140k new cases before the total hits 3.6m, the daily new case *average* over the next 33 days would have to be below 4,237. Total cases of COVID-19 in Canada (as of 2022-03-29)
Days until 2022-05-01: 33
Current total cases: 3,460,172
Daily average new cases, 14 day average: 5,936
Daily average new cases, 7 day average: 5,893

Currently at 3.45M cases.  Past the Omicron peak and holding between 4-5k cases per day.   If that holds, then by 1 May that 4000 x 32 = 128k new cases by then which is just under 3.6M (3.58).  If its more like 5000 a day, then its just under so cases will have to stay flat and hold for the next month.  there is still more BA.2 variant room to gain so this plateau could hold but I am leaning with @Emking that its not clear.  Look at those daily oscillations to see which side of the number will prevail,  if closer to 4000 it will just be under,  if closer to 5000 per day it will make it.  I am hedging downward.

It's still not clear on which side of the cut score we will land. Balancing forces of increasing spread and lower testing rates lead to very unpredictable conclusions. I'll hang out in the uncertainty zone for now, as I'm not nearly as confident as the crowd.

Increasingly liklihood given the recent rise in average cases over the last 10 days or so (now >5500) which if it stays at this pace (given the new varaint / a post-holiday "pop") should get us above 3.6m within the next 33 days (average cases needed would be ~4500). So high liklihood here.
correcting forecast as I had clicked the wrong question for my previous update.

The BA.2 wave is starting in the USA so difficult to imagine travel continues trending up.  Excluding January data for 2022 gives a 99% chance of hitting the target.  Including January reduces to 70%.  With the new wave which as I understand is higher R0 (estimated around 12 vs Omicron's 9) and unknown virulence adds uncertainty so I am reluctant to keep a forecast in the 90s.   Seeing the rolling 7 day average drop back below 2 million ( currently 2.116)  would decrease the probability further.

With 33 days to go 4800 cases per day are needed.  Current rates are on the increase again ranking at over 6k per day.
As across a lot of countries there is another wave of infection going around.  This probably won’t peak for another week or so, looking at how the curves seen (just eye balling them).   This question is likely to resolve in the middle to end April I think looking at the numbers and curve profiles.  Nothing more scientific in my maths than that!
current rate is 5,500/day * 33 days = 181K and only 150K are needed.  cases have held steady for the past few weeks and the new BA variant will likely cause new cases to rise.
Not as sure now looking at the average required today (4,678).

Daily cases has gone up. Straight-line projection shows >3.6M before end of April. Though BA.2 won't be monstrously bad, it's bringing the daily case numbers up world-wide. Total cases of COVID-19 in Canada (as of 2022-03-24)
Days until 2022-05-01: 38
Current total cases: 3,429,601
Daily average new cases, 14 day average: 5,662
Daily average new cases, 7 day average: 5,864

Forecasting an actual level here would be pretty difficult, but thankfully we don't need to. The UK saw a quick bounce up and down because of the BA2 variant, but BA2 has been present in the US, UK, Canada, and other countries since December of last year. I'm not really sure why the quick bounce didn't happen in the US/Canada, or why its been so delayed if its going to happen. Recent news seem to suggest that Canada will see another bump, or at least a plateau from BA2 now with rising caseloads, wastewater testing, reopening, etc. Cases could plateau at a lower level than current one and we'd still hit 3.6M before the deadline though, so very solid odds considering the situation.

Currently looks to be a close one, but the question is whether the rate of new cases will continue stable/downwards or break upwards as seems to be the trend in other places around the world. Keep in mind that testing rate in Canada continues to fall.
Today at 3.45, between "breakthrough cases" and next variant, I am more than highly confident.
Based on what's happening in the UK, as but one example: https://twitter.com/dgurdasani1/status/1507329507329548293

Repeating forecast. 170.4k to go. The decline in cases seems to have ended, and reported cases may be starting to go up now because of BA.2. 5.7k/day now and rising. 36 days left in forecast. 170.4/5.7 = 29.9 days => 30 days at this rate. But the rate will likely increase. The question should resolve to yes in less than 4 weeks, possibly substantially less.

It seems like the spread is spiking again and this reversal invalidates my whole premise. Crucially, the 7-day pace is higher than 14-, 21-, and 28-day paces. ==== Data Summary as of March 24 ==== Average Daily Cases:
07-day: 5,864.29
14-day: 5,662.43
21-day: 5,660.48
28-day: 5,691.29 At these paces, here is where the total case count would land:
07-day pace: 3,646,579.73
14-day pace: 3,639,110.91
21-day pace: 3,639,038.76
28-day pace: 3,640,178.73

It seems like the spread is spiking again and this reversal invalidates my whole premise. Crucially, the 7-day pace is higher than 14-, 21-, and 28-day paces. ==== Data Summary as of March 24 ==== Average Daily Cases:
07-day: 5,864.29
14-day: 5,662.43
21-day: 5,660.48
28-day: 5,691.29 At these paces, here is where the total case count would land:
07-day pace: 3,646,579.73
14-day pace: 3,639,110.91
21-day pace: 3,639,038.76
28-day pace: 3,640,178.73

Current 7 day case averages well above threshold to break 3.6 million or more (5,864 for a 7 day avg...4,733 case 7 day avg required to be below 3.6 million). Trend for increased community spread due to weather and COVID restrictions loosening now make this highly likely.
A lot of progress to the target was made this week.

It appears the 7-day average has plateaued (At current rates should just pass threshold) and shows signs it may be beginning an uptrend. With lifting of mask and vaccine restrictions and increasing cases in other parts of the world it appears to me we are most likely to see at least some upward pressure on the daily infection rate. Waste water also shows indication of a increase in cases coming. (Thanks @belikewater)  If we are in the beginning of an uptrend daily cases that means the R value has raised above 1 at least for a bit and we should expect daily cases to start to increase rapidly for a while before dropping back. In this case we should easily surpass this threshold. (even if we return to this level or lower before the end of the window) I am leaving a 10% margin of error to account for the case where the apparent reversal of the downward trend is simply noise rather that a sign of what's to come, or if less severe cases (as a result of vaccines and naturally developed immune response) result in lower official numbers over time.
Recent leading indicators suggest that avg daily case count will rise, not fall, which should cause the total count to surpass the threshold within the timeframe (assuming constant testing rates...)
Some parts of the world are showing a rapid increase again that could peak.

Ontario wastewater is showing exponential growth in SARS-CoV-2 viral load.
https://twitter.com/DrKateTO/status/1506949730533842945
Other provinces are also showing growth.
All that is needed for this question to resolve to yes is for cases to remain flat. If cases grow a bit for a few weeks and then decline a bit, it will resolve to yes. March 23's 7-day average of cases was 5320/day, and recent numbers have bounced around between 4.2k/day and 5.3k/day. The total as of March 23 was 3,419,779, so 180,221 left to go. 38 days left in forecast. 180,221/38 = 4742.7. So if the average 7-day average remains at or above 4743/day (approximately where it is now), then the question will resolve to yes. This looks extremely likely, given that we are likely to soon see a bump in cases from BA.2.

If the current rate were to hold steady, the total would just barely cross the threshold before the question ends. Therefore, this question is asking if we think cases will increase or decrease over the next month. My intuition is that the counts will fall.

200k per required and 37 days to get them at 5400/ day.
Currently sitting at 5000 per day and has increased from 4300 over the last 10 days. BA2 is increasing and could drive an upturn like in other countries.

In my first forecast I said: "40 days until 1 May, 214946 cases required to reach 3.6 million. Average cases/day needs to be 5373.65.
Current average is 4397.43, so 22% increase in average daily cases required, and cases are falling albeit slowly." There has been an increase in average case/day to 5320 over the last few days. Granted the average required over the period has now increased since there are only ~36 days left. I think once we start seeing a rise in cases like this, it's likely to spike, confirming Canada is following the BA.2 pattern seen in Europe. Every day the case averages over that required minimum to reach 3.6 million reduces the average that needs to be held. At this point my forecast is based on the likelihood that Canada replicates what has happened in the UK, where the inital Omicron BA.1 wave happened at almost the same time (start and peak).  Canada actually experienced a lower peak in terms of cases/100,000 than the UK. If BA.2 is much more transmissable but those infected with BA.1 are unlikely to catch it again, that might point to the possibility that Canada could see a significantly larger spike than the UK this time around as there is a larger susceptible population.

"Surveillance of wastewater data is suggesting that COVID-19 cases are on the rise again in Canada as provinces have eased public health restrictions."
https://twitter.com/globalnews/status/1506819720267374598
Current low rate of 2500 cases per day I wouldn’t expect to see 3.6 million broken

Reaffirming my previous estimate: as iof today, linear extrapolation based on cases of the last 7 days points to an extremely close call just a few thousand cases below 3.6 million by the end of April. The curve currently seems to flatten slightly, which points to a negative resolution of the question. But even a small uptick could bring the case count above the threshold. Until the impact of Easter (increased travelling within Canada, cases imported by European visitor) can be determined, I am staying slightly below 50% if nothing else changes. Will be updating as new data becomes available, but this will most probably remain a close call until the very last days.
Extrapolating the data linearly based on the last 2 points would go over 3.6M, but the curve seems to be flattening.

Ontario cases are most likely about to start going up.
https://twitter.com/Billius27/status/1506481424395902977

As of March 22, 187,576 to go to reach 3.6M. 39 days remaining in forecast. Cases must remain at or above 4910/day to reach 3.6M. The 7-day average of cases/day has hovered between 4.2k/day and 5.3k/day over the past week. Cases are close to plateauing but may still be gently declining, and an increase in cases from BA.2 for the country as a whole may still be 2 or 3 weeks away. This will likely be a very close forecast.
As of March 15th, the 7-day case count was 34,610. As of today, March 23rd, the 7-day case count is 35,360. The rates are going up and at this pace they will surpass the 3.6 million mark.

Daily cases didn't drop off nearly as much as I'd thought they would. Total cases of COVID-19 in Canada (as of 2022-03-21)
Days until 2022-05-01: 40
Current total cases: 3,404,283
Daily average new cases, 14 day average: 5,114
Daily average new cases, 7 day average: 4,922

The downtrend in the data that I thought was there is really not, so it is bouncing along very near a target pace.  The risks seem pretty asymmetric that there could be large daily jumps up but only small drops lower.  And there are some signs of a new wave globally and now migrating to the US.  It is possibly related to the new Omicron subvariant but I don't think there are any firm conclusions about that.

Have no idea and didn't research this. Mild cases are not going to be counted-no need to and with many Canadians getting the shots, under reporting will happen. Get your shots or suffer the consequences.
Edging this back up a little as cases are picking up slightly.

current 3.33 mil
time to event 52 days 
100k per 14 days > 3.7 times
+370k 
expected 3.7 mil
20th of March data showed a slowdown from previous trend, will monitor but for moment need to drop my forecast.

That's 48 days to go, and at the current pace of 5,300 a day added to the current total of 3.36 million it would be just over 3.6 million. Cases have been trending down, but Europe has also seen a recent uptick happen. Overall I think it's slightly more likely than not that it surpasses, particularly with the potential for new Omicron variants to gain dominance and the possibility for reinfection. https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Color+by+test+positivity=false&country=~CAN

As of the March 20 data, the rate of daily cases has continued to slow. Average Daily Cases:
07-day: 4,529.00 
14-day: 5,040.36
21-day: 5,218.43
28-day: 5,390.46 At these paces, here is where the total case count would land:
07-day pace: 3,583,282.00
14-day pace: 3,604,247.76
21-day pace: 3,611,548.63
28-day pace: 3,618,601.86 EDIT: I may have to revisit this today as I think harder about BA.2, but for now I'm tabling that.
Average cases from 11 Mar to 20 Mar is 4,529/day, adjusting slightly based on rate being below threshold average to achieve 3.6 million cases before 1 May.
Case rates slowing and as approx 30,000 cases per week at the moment, if the trend continues to slow as it has done in other areas it would probably fall just shy of the target

as of March 17 there was a shade over 3.3 million cases in Canada and the trend chart looks like maybe reaching peak...1 May is 41 days away - would need daily cases of 5200 to hit the 3.6 million; 7 day rolling case average is hovering around the 50k mark - so there is the potential...

Currently at 3,385,054 cases. 40 days until 1 May, 214946 cases required to reach 3.6 million. Average cases/day needs to be 5373.65.
Current average is 4397.43, so 22% increase in average daily cases required, and cases are falling albeit slowly. BA2 however makes this more complicated than that. I think it's quite likely that Canada will see a modest surge in cases over the next few weeks. If cases don't start rising again by the end of the month, then I will re-assess.

About 215k more cases to hit 3.6 mil, and lately the trend in new cases has been steady to lower (34,727 cases is the 7-day average). At this rate, it would take 43 days, bringing us to exactly May 1st. So the question is, are cases going up or down from here? Worldwide, BA.2 is leading to yet another spike, and I would think something similar to happen in Canada, especially with recent relaxing of restrictions across the country. Leaning towards up (at least, if people are tested for it!).
Cases are undeniably going up globally, and in Europe. I am optimistic that seasonal effects will cancel out the new surge before it takes off too badly but very hard to say
Adjusting since the case reduction over the last 7 days rose instead of going down as I previously anticipated.
The evidence starts to suggest that BA.2 prevalence may well be the deciding factor in tippping the total just above 3.6M. Early days, but it starts to look more likely than not.
Cases seem be continue to rise. Currently at nearly 3.4 so could hit 3.6

Cases continue to decline, but slowly. BA.2 is rapidly growing as a percentage of new cases and is now approaching 40% of new cases. It will overtake Omicron shortly. It would be reasonable to expect some uptick in cases once most cases are caused by BA.2, as upticks are being seen elsewhere (e.g., Europe), BA.2 is even more contagious than Omicron, BA.2 is antigenically somewhat different from Omicron, and immunity is fading. Increasing my forecast very slightly.
I put 75% for the 'one and done' forecast but I am reducing here to see how cases evolve over the next week.
Currently at 3.3M, lowest rate of change was 100k/month in 2021 during delta.  Omicron more infectious, so even at lowest rate it would be close.

The PHAC website has current cases at 3,360,446 (https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html?stat=num&measure=total&map=pt#a2). Using Worldometer was easier to get approximate total cases on certain dates (https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html?stat=num&measure=total&map=pt#a2). In order to get to 3.6 million there would have to be an increase of 239,554 cases over about a month and a half timeline. Only twice over the 17 week and a half iterations that I counted has the total case rate surpassed the required amount. Worldometer counted 3,066,492 on 01FEB  and 1,845,256 on 14DEC (I’m assuming that is close to what PHAC counted, other numbers are similar). Other than these counts, total marginal cases have been fewer. Given the downward trend in total cases, I’m going to assess that the probability will be closer to the 2 of 17 (12%) chance. The downward trend makes me want to decrease this percentage, but I will keep it for now.

TIL, that the .csv files provided on the linked website are changing data for the past dates, not just adding the latest day's data.  If anyone has saved copies of a lot of old .csv files it would be interesting to get an idea of how far back they will make changes. The change I noticed was ~60 cases added in the 15 March total when the 16 March data was added.  Changes that are small and go back a day can probably be ignored.  It might be bigger revisions around holidays and weekends though as that seems to be the nature of CoVID case reporting data.  There may have been bigger changes also.  I remember seeing a reported daily case number around 2500 a few days ago but the lowest number in the recent .csv rows is 3500.  This may be some kind of intraday update that may be unrelated to changing past date totals. The question wording may be confusing for this style of data updating as the time the data is read will impact the resolution.  There is ambiguity about time of reporting vs which row of the .csv file (which date) would be read.  The top line says that the 3,600,000 or higher must be reported before 1 May but the fine print allows for data access until 5 May.  One interpretation of resolution is reading the Canada total from the map graphic at 11:59PM on 30 April (maybe even reading it constantly up to that time if cases can also be revised lower).  A second interpretation is that the .csv file could be accessed up to 5 May 11:59PM and the Canada - Total Cases - from April 30th will be used to resolve.    I am not sure which resolution style seems more likely.  Resolving based on the April 30th Total cases and allowing for updates of that total to 5 May seems very reasonable but I am not sure how that gets wedged into 'Canada reported x cases before 1 May' when the number is clearly being reported after 1 May.  The total cases displayed next to the map appears important to the resolution criteria but reading that number up to 5 May would mean including data and total cases a few days after the 1 May date in the top line. For small recent revisions these different resolution interpretations probably also don't matter.  Maybe a 3% chance of a voided question since we are very near the pace need to resolve right at the threshold.

The recent BA-2 variant of Omicron has significantly sent cases surging across Asia and Europe who usually predate the spread in the Americas by a week or two. Given the non-compliance with or lack of containment rules, this makes these cases numbers very plausible.

3/17:  Current case count is 3,379,196; 220,804 from threshold.  45 days in the question remain, so 4907 cases/day which would take us back to early December case rates (current rate is higher).  Rates are dropping though, so I've left room for that to occur.  But  still with the current deviation, I think it is likely to occur.
BA.2 becoming dominant means that we are likely to see at least a small rise in cases https://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/omicron-ba-2-subvariant-becoming-dominant-representing-potential-risk

As of writing this forecast Canada is sitting at 3.39 Million cases total, meaning that it would need to record >210,000 new cases in the next 45 days. with a current new daily case count of ~5,300. At the current rate we would expect the total to hit 3,628,500 cases total by May 1st. (Practically right on the threshold.) Meaning largely the determining factor will be if the rate continues to fall (Dropping the total below the threshold), or if we plateau on see a rise in the rate of infection again. I think that while we have seen a recent trend down from the peak of the omicron wave that may continue, with the lifting of mask mandates and restrictions I think more likely we see the trend plateau or a small increase in the rate as people begin interacting more. I am leaving a 45% chance that the trend continues with no hick-ups during reopening.

As of writing we would need about 5k cases a day to get to 3.6m by May first. Over the last month or so the average count has been ~5500 but it seems to be declining (last 7 days = 4,900). So we're right on the cusp which puts me around 50% chance but I'm going to lean that the trend is your friend and go to 40%. Now there's two inside factors to consider: 1) March break bump given increased travel+testing necessity. That will certainly lead to two weeks of increased positive rates in my view. Secondarily, we're loosening more restrictions across Canada, particularly in population heavy Toronto, which could drive more infections. On the other hand, with reduced restrictions + less testing requiremnets (particularly travel on April 1) I think we'll see a rise in unreported cases which doesn't impact the case count for the purposes of this question. Also, entering "warmer months" in Canada may reduce spread as people are outside more.

Going up a bit. As we're seeing in Europe right now, cases can peak with Omicron and then start going back up again as BA.2 comes into play. I'm not sure how realistic it is for BA.2 to cause enough of an increase in cases due to the short timeline for this question, but it's enough to re-assess my initial forecast. How/if restrictions and isolation rules change will play a role e.g., in the UK you no longer need to self-isolate if you have symptoms/test positive, which unsurprisingly does not help to lower cases.

as of 15 Mar, total cases = 3,373,339. 3,600,000 - 3,373,339 = 226,661
There are 46 days left before 1 May. Then, we need avg. 4,937 dailly cases.

Using comparative data from delta variant case curve, vaccination rates then vs now, and modeling data of a similar country (US) an outside view can be established.   As of 11 Mar, roughly 257,000 cases must be reported before 1 May equating to just over 5,000 cases per day.  In the case of the delta variant, we see similar numbers of cases but with lower vaccination rates (81% now in Canada) as well as lower numbers of access to self-testing kits (possibly lowering the population's will to officially report vice initiate self-isolation).   Given omicron's natural immunity, high vaccination rates, and trend data post variant suggesting significant case drops the likelihood of 3.6 million or more total cases is relatively low in Canada.

I'd estimate the total on 1st may at ~3.45-3.7M, in others words too close to call. Cases should continue to decline for a least a couple of weeks, perhaps down to 3,500/day, but then we have to factor in BA.2 increasing in prevalence, mask mandates easing, and booster shots at <50% population. There must be high acquired immunity from the Omicron wave, but BA.2 is already at ~20% and perhaps 30-40% more transmissible. I don't think seasonal changes will help enough to prevent greater spread through April as people become less cautious or even reactionary towards mask wearing, so we could see cases climbing slowly through April.

Reported cases are declining, and official policy is now to concentrate on hospitalizations, so many cases will go unreported to authorities. However, the situation may change if another variant spreads in the next six weeks.

Currently, to resolve the question positively, roughly 230'000 are missing. There were roughly 35'000 cases in the past 7 days, trend is declining. At the current rate this would be mean Canada would come in slightly below 3.6mio cases in 6 weeks time. However, the margin is small here. My estimate will need update as the deadline move closer and more data becomes available.

I counted 4 periods out of 15 (26%) where the 48 day case increase was big enough to reach the target.  But the 7 day average case rate is currently at a rate that will hit the target.  It is tempting to assume the down trend in the case average will continue but I am not very certain of that as the shape and level of the troughs probably varies with different variants, seasonality, and societal adaptations.   So I will start nearer 50% and expect to come down quickly if the 7 day average keeps falling.

This is a tricky and well-posed question. 3.37M as of March 14. 232,708 to go. Currently, a 7-day average of 4,548 cases/day and falling. 47 days from March 15 through April 30. An average of 232,708/47 = 4951.2 cases/day would need to be reported for Canada to reach 3.6 million reported cases by April 30 ("Before 1 May"). Cases are likely to go up a bit as a BA.2 wave arrives, but that wave will probably be very small. A lot of Canadians recently got Omicron, and spring is coming. BA.2 is currently causing about 20% of all new cases (see https://outbreak.info/location-reports?loc=CAN ), and that percentage can be expected to increase. It's as contagious as measles and substantially antigenically different from Omicron, so it shouldn't be underestimated. The US is just behind Canada in the percentage of cases due to BA.2, and many locations are starting to see an uptick in SARS-CoV-2 RNA in wastewater; cases in the US are likely to start rising soon. I think it's safe to expect that cases in Canada will likely start rising soon, as well. As I said above, I think the BA.2 wave will be very small, but it might be enough to prevent the average cases/day from falling below 4951/day in the forecast period. I think this question could be very close, and the total could easily end up within 20k of 3.6M. I think it's somewhat unlikely that 3.6M will be reached by May 1, but I'm not nearly as certain as the crowd that 3.6M won't be reached.
